channel.title: Drivers for Fedora
channel.description:
Ok I decided to get Fedora 10 because of all the hassle I have been through and Fedora seems to be the most stable.
I need instructions on how to install a Broadcom STA driver for Fedora 10, since in Ubuntu it said I needed a Broadcom STA driver and that seems to work great with long distance wifi spots.
And for my desktop I need specific instructions on how to install a Nvidia Geforce 6150SE for Fedora 10.
Thanks for your help in making Linux > Windows.

item.title: Drivers for Fedora
item.dc:creator: @bjc22 bjc22
item.description:
@bjc22 wrote:

Its a non-free driver Broadcom made for linux not too long ago.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: December 01, 2008, 08:59:01 pm[/size][hr]Nevermind I got it, in Fedora the Broadcom STA driver was known as broadcom-wl

Read full topic

item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Is that a windows driver? I’ve never heard of broadcom STA.

Read full topic

item.title: Drivers for Fedora
item.dc:creator: @bjc22 bjc22
item.description:
@bjc22 wrote:

Umm like at the campground, if I use b43 the signal is very low and I am only shows up on the list maybe for 10 seconds then goes away for an hour. With the Broadcom STA driver it is almost full signal and it is very fast…

Read full topic

item.title: Drivers for Fedora
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

What is ‘long distance wifi’? I don’t see how it would be different than regular wifi.

Read full topic

item.title: Drivers for Fedora
item.dc:creator: @bjc22 bjc22
item.description:
@bjc22 wrote:

Yeah I always google everything, I don’t like the b43 driver because it doesn’t work with long distance wifi. But with Ubuntu I just selected the hardware driver “Broadcom STA driver” and it picked up routers/wifi spots that I have never gotten before, even with windows. But I don’t like Ubuntu for many reasons so I wanted a working Fedora 10 version. I googled this website right here: http://www.cenolan.com/2008/11/rpm-install-broadcom-wireless-sta-driver-fedora/

And that one did not work, so I came here hoping for a better way.

Read full topic

item.title: Drivers for Fedora

item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Does it use b43? And have you googled this? That is how I find all my linux information.
